I would love to be able to sit down and have a good, long discussion with you. I'm 19, and I fell in love with your channel ages and ages ago. Science to me isn't understanding the knowledge, it's being able to apply said knowledge years, maybe decades or centuries after it's first discovery, into something useful for society. When I need to hear a big word, or watch an adventure into some crazy deal involving digging up opals in the middle of the Australian outback, or a discussion on how Astronauts maintain bone density and muscle mass, I go to you or Derek at Veritasium, maybe Vsauce too if I feel for something meta.
I'll be honest, astronomy is what I am hooked on. Mainly with Quark Stars. The second big thing I feel is engineering, aerospace engineering in particular. Like with the holes in the ISS. I love the idea of building a machine that could assist with some life challenge microgravity can cause, then taking the design and modifying it, slowly shrinking it down and making it more compact and lighter weight. If I could stand in your shoes on one of these adventures, I'd be the happiest fish in the ocean.
But I have two questions for you today. One personal, and one scientific.
To an outside observer, science is several different branches of the same tree. Physics and biology are not the same. However, they heavily, and I mean HEAVILY depend upon each other and alter factors of the other. Where do you think the split between two branches exists, or is it like a sponge, all one thing but with pockets of ignorance and some areas blending together in some fourth dimensional scientific love fest?
Secondly, I wanted to ask more upon your religious beliefs. You have many more years on life than I do, and we have come to polarized opinions on this topic. I am not a believer of the Bible or any other religious text. In short, I'm an atheist. To me this makes logical sense and has altered many relationships. At what point did you become rooted in your faith, and why does it make perfect sense to you?

Bed Stuff - Latex beds are great, but I had to go with a Gel Infused Memory Foam. Latex conforms just like Memory foam, but it's more firm. Latex has the fastest expansion rate (keeps you from getting stuck in a rut), and they breath the most (keeps you cool). Memory foam is squishy,  and very slow at returning to shape, they also sleep very warm. Gel infused Memory foam sits in the middle in all categories. My girlfriend wanted Memory foam, because she loves being warm, and she loved how soft they are. I wanted Latex, because I like the confirming but firm feel, and I prefer to sleep cool. We met in the middle on the Gel Memory Foam.

There is no such thing as, "faith supported by reason". Faith is unreasonable by definition, and is intellectually dishonest. Faith as attributing more confidence to a belief than the evidence alone warrants. It means actively wanting and trying to believe in something, often in spite of any evidence, or worse, in spite of evidence to the contrary (for proof of this, look up the "statement of faith" on every creationist organizations website.)When is this ever a wise, logical, or intellectually honest thing to do? Why is it that faith is only considered a good thing when it comes to gods and religion? Imagine if a scientist, or historian, or a doctor demanded faith in his theories or claims instead of citing evidence. He would rightly be ignored, and probably laughed at.
